item.title: Natural Deduction with Derived Rules Answers
item.description: Proof-solutions for the exercise on TFL natural deduction with derived rules is → here. An important caveat: these are only the solutions I happened to see first, and which seemed to me at least as efficient as other solutions I immediately saw. There are always many other solutions, and especially many other legitimate ways of ordering inferences. So, your answer that’s quite unlike what I’ve done isn’t necessarily wrong! You might consider checking it with the forall x proof checker.

item.title: FOL Parentheses
item.description: The following specifies where, for your work in this course, parentheses are and are not optional in First Order Logic: Textbook Section 26.4 allows us to omit the outermost brackets of any formula (so, “P⋁Q” is just as good as “(P⋁Q)”). And it allows square brackets (“[” and “]”) in place of parentheses wherever we feel it increases readability. Our textbook generally does not put parentheses around quantifiers, like ∀x and ∃x.

item.title: Variant Rule Names
item.description: In the Basic deduction rules for TFL (summarized in textbook Appendix C, section 3.4), the names of the negation rules are a little confusing. I’m not the first instructor using this textbok to point this out. So, I offer you the following alternatives. In a natural deduction proof, in your justification column, you may optionally invoke the contradiction rule (¬E) by writing “contradiction” or “contra.” instead; because ¬I and IP are symmetrical rules1, but not named symmetrically, you may optionally invoke ¬I by calling it “IP” In other words, I won’t mark those two alternatives wrong on homework or tests.

item.title: Topic 6: Causation
item.description: We’ve discussed what correlations are, and how they are related to sampling from a population via basic probability ideas. But we noted that correlation isn’t causation, and that researchers are quite often interested in causation. Here we take up how it might be possible to investigate causal relationships, and some of the challenges and limitations inherent to doing that. Reading “Understanding and Misunderstanding Randomized Controlled Trials” by Angus Deaton and Nancy Cartwright.

item.title: Topic 5: Frequentism
item.description: Next, we examine the second main, contemporary approach to scientific reasoning, based in the frequentist understanding of probability. At the heart of its reasoning is the “double negative” inference, based in the “probabilistic modus tollens.” The jargon name for this approach is “null hypothesis significance testing.” We will observe how and why it works, building up from some foundational concepts. Reading Hacking, Chapter 16 “Stability” Hacking, Chapter 17 “Normal Approximations” Hacking, Chapter 18 “Significance and Power” (note on type I/II error) Slides Introducing null-hypothesis testing (Apr 13) Introduction to population sampling and correlation (updated Apr 16; slide 11 is new) See also “Statistical Tests, P Values, Confidence Intervals, and Power: A Guide to Misinterpretations” by Sander Greenland et al.

item.title: Topic 4: Bayesianism
item.description: Bayesianism, as an approach to inductive reasoning, focuses on updating our beliefs in light of new evidence. It is built around a simple formula that expreses a relationship between probabilities. Reading Hacking, Chapter 7 “Bayes' Rule” (pages 69–77) Hacking, Chapter 13 “Personal Probabilities” (pages 151–160) Hacking, Chapter 21 “Learning from Experience as an Evasion of the Problem of Induction” (4 pages) — and if you’re not feeling sufficiently familiar with “the problem of induction,” look at the first pages of Chapter 20 See also John Horgan, “Bayes’s Theorem: What’s the Big Deal?

item.title: Topic 3: Probability
item.description: Here we set up some basic ideas about probability which will be key for understanding the approaches to scientific justification which have dominated the last several decades. Reading Hacking, Introduction to Probability and Inductive Logic Chapter 4 “Elementary Probability Ideas” Chapter 5 “Conditional Probability” Chapter 11 “What Do You Mean?” Slides Probability Probability-2 Note: These are PDFs which you should be able to view easily.

item.title: Assignment 1
item.description: Upload your assignment to the Blackboard link for Assignments by Feb 21. Tasks Produce your own original examples of: a deductively valid, sound argument a deductively valid argument which is not sound an inductively strong argument a version of that same argument which is even stronger an argument which sounds a little plausible and might actually persuade someone not being careful about their reasoning, but which is neither deductively valid nor inductively strong Use your imagination and powers of observation a bit: What are some different ways inductive arguments can have more inductive strength than others?

item.title: Topic 2: Early Methods
item.description: As modern science emerged, its practitioners tried to describe how they were reasoning, and how others should reason, to do science. They came to quite different answers! This unit looks quickly at a few landmarks from the period 1600–1900. Reading Francis Bacon, The New Organon (1620). Read Book 2, sections 10–16 (this starts on page 53 of the linked PDF), but skim through the examples to get a general sense of what’s going on with them, and focus on the beginning and end.

item.title: Topic 1: Logic
item.description: What is logic? What is deductive logic? Could deductive logic be the logic of science? Is non-deductive logic possible? Reading (This is what you should read for this section. The due dates appear on the front page schedule.) Ian Hacking, An Introduction to Probability and Inductive Logic (purchased book) Chapter 1 “Logic”, whole chapter, pages 1–7. Robin Smith, “Aristotle’s Logic” in the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy. Read the brief/unnumbered preface then sections 1, 2, 3, and 6.

item.title: Participation Rubric
item.description: This is the participation rubric to be used for grading participation in this course. Read it as saying “A student who demonstrates … earns a grade of X,” where X is the letter grade at the top of the column.1 A B C D F Active role in discussions, drawing on texts Regular, constructive participation drawing on texts Inconsistent constructive participation based on texts Vague comments reflecting limited engagement with texts Persistent lack of engagement with texts Full preparation for approximately every class Substantial preparation, normally Inconsistent evidence of preparation Rare evidence of participation No positive evidence of participation Success at advancing level and depth of discussion, persistently Regular contributions based on assigned material, which sometimes improve discussion and never diminish it Rare or no significant contribution to the level of discussion while not reducing it Activity sometimes diminishing the discussion and the classroom environment Activity regularly diminishing the discussion and the classroom environment Active engagement with and listening to peers, persistently Sincere efforts to interact with peers, normally Limited engagement with peers Rare interaction with peers No interaction with peers This rubric is significantly based on, and lightly adapted from, one written by another philosophy professor, Jay Odenbaugh.
